bibl.title: Despatch from Alexander G. Clark to William F. Wharton, December 31, 1890
Despatches from United States Consuls in Monrovia, 1852-1906

correspAction.roleName: U.S. Minister Resident and Consul General

div1.p: Consulate General of the United States, Monrovia Liberia December 31, 1890, Mr Alexander Clark to Department of State

These accounts are to include the Sept Quarter ending Sept 30th Rent. and the December Quarter ending December 31/90 also vouchers for said accounts as far as I could &c made it is all most imposible to seamen vouchers for every small expense of the Legation as may I am compiler to each without bills. also please inform if I am to give oath before another repalm from amount of fee colected as a list of fees to the caster from office and also cirtified in by report & The above information I desire under that may be governed by & c
Consulate General of the United States, Monrovia Liberia December 31, 1890.
To the Honorable William F. Wharton Assistant Secretary of State Washington D. C.

Sir: I have the honor to advise that I have drawn Draft No 2 for contingent expenses $228 37/100 Dollars on the Secretary of State in favor of R. A. Sherman; also Draft No 3 on account of salary $478 Dollars on the Secretary of State in favor of myself endorsed to George W. Appleton All of said drafts for the Quarters ending Sept 30/1890 and December 31 1890 per accompanying accounts.

I have further to request that you supply the legation with some blank drafts as there is not one left and I was compleled to use. Sole of exchange for my Sallary draft, also there is no abstract blank left except 2 and sallery. blanks and fus. I am satisfied that department can furnish them by mail cheaper than they can be printed because they would have to be printed in Liverpool or London as there are no printers established here
I have the honor to be your obedient servant, Aledander Clark Minister Resident
